# Authentication

## Overview

<!-- Describe the authentication strategy used by the {{repoName}} API. -->

## Authentication Methods

### Bearer Token (OAuth 2.0)

All API requests must include a valid bearer token in the `Authorization` header:

```
Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN
```

### Obtaining a Token

```bash
curl -X POST https://api.example.com/v1/auth/token \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"client_id": "YOUR_ID", "client_secret": "YOUR_SECRET"}'
```

**Response 200:**

```json
{
  "access_token": "eyJhbG...",
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "expires_in": 3600
}
```

## Token Lifecycle

| Event | Behaviour |
|-------|-----------|
| Token issued | Valid for `expires_in` seconds |
| Token expired | Returns `401 Unauthorised` |
| Token revoked | Returns `401 Unauthorised` |

## API Keys

<!-- If API keys are supported, describe how they are generated and used. -->

## Scopes & Permissions

| Scope | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| `read` | Read-only access to resources |
| `write` | Create and update resources |
| `admin` | Full administrative access |

## Security Best Practices

- Store tokens securely; never expose them in client-side code.
- Rotate secrets regularly.
- Use short-lived tokens with refresh token rotation.
